questions.text: What procedure is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows a sentinel lymph node biopsy using a gamma camera.

The sentinel lymph node is the first draining lymph node. SLNB was first described in penile cancer by Cabana. Sentinel lymph node biopsy is only done on node-negative tumors.

Methylene blue dye or radioisotope i.e., technetium-labeled albumin is injected into breast tissue (or subdermal tissue) at the site of the primary tumor or at the subareolar position. The sentinel node is identified as a blue node or as a radioactive node (using a gamma camera). The frozen section biopsy is sent to the pathologist for identification of cancer cells. If the biopsy is positive for cancer cells, then axillary dissection is simultaneously performed. 

Note: The combination of blue dye and technetium-labeled colloid has been reported to improve the detection of sentinel lymph nodes. Newer techniques involve the use of a fluorescent or magnetic tracer instead of the radiolabelled dye.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding sentinel lymph node biopsy in a patient with a T2 N1 M0 breast tumour?

choices.text: If biopsy is positive, then axillary dissection is not done
If biopsy is negative, then axillary dissection is done
If biopsy is positive then tumour free margin should be > 2 cm

questions.solution: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is only done in node-negative tumors. It is not done in N1 stage tumors.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a lump in her right breast. On examination, a 3 cm palpable mass is felt in the right upper quadrant of the right breast. A mammogram is suggestive of a malignant lesion. Biopsy confirmed invasive ductal carcinoma with no nodal involvement. How will you manage this patient?

choices.text: Breast conservation therapy with adjuvant radiotherapy
Modified radical mastectomy with adjuvant radiotherapy

questions.solution:
This patient has stage T2 breast carcinoma. These patients are managed with breast conservation therapy with adjuvant radiotherapy.

Indications of breast conservation surgery (BCS):

  1. DCIS/Tis tumors
  2. T1-2 tumors
  3. No contraindication for adjuvant radiotherapy
  4. Excision with clear margins is possible
  5. Who does not want a mastectomy
  6. Locally advanced tumors with excellent response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy.

Prefixes for TNM staging:

  • c: clinical staging (e.g. cT1b)
  • p: pathological (histological) staging
  • y: stage following systemic or radiation therapy (either prior to surgery or as a primary treatment)
  • r: staging at the time of retreatment or recurrence for disease progression

Suffix for TNM staging:

  • m: multiple primary tumours of the same histology in the same organ, e.g. T2(m) or T2(5), the latter meaning that there are five primary tumours

Related Pearl: Contraindications for Breast Conservative Surgery

Absolute contraindications:

  • 1st-trimester pregnancy
  • Diffuse microcalcifications
  • Persistently positive pathologic margin
  • Multicentric tumor

Relative contraindications:

  • Connective tissue disorders like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE),  scleroderma and rheumatoid arthritis
  • Large lump-to-breast ratio, i.e., a big lump in small breast
  • Lump beneath the nipple-areola complex
  • Multifocal tumor
  • History of therapeutic radiation exposure to the chest wall

NOTE : Some authorities do not consider Rheumatoid Arthritis as a relative contraindication as the data on radiation toxicity in RA is sparse.

questions.text:
Breast conservative surgery can be performed in which of the following patients with breast carcinoma?
  1. A post-partum woman
  2. A small breasted woman with a large lump
  3. A woman with a tumor that has a persistently positive pathologic margin
  4. A woman with diffuse micro-calcification on a mammogram
  5. A woman with a history of therapeutic radiation exposure to the chest wall
questions.solution:
Breast conservation surgery can be done in a post-partum woman.

Breast cancer diagnosed during the second or third trimester can be managed with breast conservation surgery followed by adjuvant chemotherapy. 

For breast cancer diagnosed late in the third trimester, breast conservation surgery can be performed, deferring breast irradiation until after delivery.

Breast cancer diagnosed during the first trimester should be treated with mastectomy. Breast conservation surgery is contraindicated in the first trimester since post-operative radiotherapy cannot be deferred for a long time and chemotherapy is contraindicated in the first trimester.

Related Pearl: Contraindications for Breast Conservative Surgery

Absolute contraindications:

  • 1st-trimester pregnancy
  • Diffuse microcalcifications
  • Persistently positive pathologic margin
  • Multicentric tumor

Relative contraindications:

  • Connective tissue disorders like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE),  scleroderma and rheumatoid arthritis
  • Large lump-to-breast ratio, i.e., a big lump in small breast
  • Lump beneath the nipple-areola complex
  • Multifocal tumor
  • History of therapeutic radiation exposure to the chest wall

NOTE : Some authorities do not consider Rheumatoid Arthritis as a relative contraindication as the data on radiation toxicity in RA is sparse.

questions.text: A patient with early breast carcinoma of stage T3 N0 M0 does not want to undergo mastectomy. What is the next best treatment of choice in her case?

choices.text: Breast conservation surgery followed by radiation therapy
Chemotherapy alone since mastectomy is the only option
Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by breast conservation surgery
Mastectomy only since it is a large operable tumour

questions.solution:
According to the clinical scenario, neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by breast conservation surgery (BCS) is the next best treatment.

Stage T3 N0 M0 tumors are lesions of size >5 cm and are considered as large operable breast cancer (LOBC). The best management for such tumors is mastectomy.

In case the patient is not willing for mastectomy, the next best treatment is neoadjuvant chemotherapy to shrink the tumor, followed by breast conservation surgery.

questions.text: You are assisting in a modified radical mastectomy. Which of the following steps will not be done by the operating surgeon during this procedure?
questions.solution:
Pectoralis major is not removed in modified radical mastectomy.

Structures removed in modified radical mastectomy:

  1. Whole breast tissue
  2. The skin over the breast tissue
  3. Nipple-areola complex
  4. Pectoral fascia
  5. Levels I, II, ± III axillary lymph nodes

The pectoralis minor muscle is either cut (Patey's, Scanlon's modification) or retracted (Auchincloss).

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Breast conservation surgery (BCS)/WLE (wide local excision): Tumour removal with a 3D clearance of a 1 mm margin of normal tissue
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Skin-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope preservation and nipple-areola complex removal
  • Skin+ nipple/areola-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope and nipple-areola complex preservation
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Level I oncoplasty (volume displacement surgery): Tumour excision with wide margins followed by defect repair via dual-plane mobilisation of the breast parenchyma to maintain shape and symmetry
  • Level II oncoplasty (volume replacement surgery): Skin excision and glandular mobilisation involving >20% resection of breast volume
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + axillary lymph nodes (levels I + II ± III) dissection
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + internal mammary lymph nodes dissection
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iverson) mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary and supraclavicular lymph nodes dissection
  • Super radical mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary, supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph nodes dissection.

*Dual-plane mobilisation of breast parenchyma: Mobilisation of the dermoglandular plane and plane between breast parenchyma and pectoralis muscle.

questions.text: In patients with which of the following features of tumor involvement should you not perform radical mastectomy?
questions.solution:
Distant metastasis is a contraindication for radical mastectomy.

Excision of the breast, the pectoralis major and minor muscles, and all axillary lymph nodes constitute radical mastectomy. It is seldom performed given that it causes substantial morbidity due to shoulder joint restriction, pain, significant upper limb lymphedema, and chest wall deformity, with no survival advantage when compared to less radical surgery. In the case of distant metastases,  less radical surgery is of no benefit either.

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications for radical mastectomy

Indications:

  • Large, bulky tumor involving pectoralis major muscle and fascia.
  • Axillary lymph node involvement
  • Interpectoral lymph node involvement

Contraindications:

  • Non-palpable or small tumors
  • Advanced disease with distant metastasis
  • Patients who need improved cosmetic result
  • Patients who need reconstructive surgery
  • Coexisting severe systemic diseases like DM, CHF, CRF

questions.text: Which of the following structures will not be removed while performing radical mastectomy in patients with breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Supraclavicular lymph nodes are not removed in radical mastectomy.

In Halsted radical mastectomy, the following structures are removed:

  • All breast tissue and skin
  • Nipple-areolar complex
  • Pectoralis major and pectoralis minor muscles
  • Level I, II, and III axillary lymph nodes.

  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.

  • Skin+ nipple/areola-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope and nipple-areola complex preservation
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Level I oncoplasty (volume displacement surgery): Tumour excision with wide margins followed by defect repair via dual-plane mobilisation of the breast parenchyma to maintain shape and symmetry
  • Level II oncoplasty (volume replacement surgery): Skin excision and glandular mobilisation involving >20% resection of breast volume
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + axillary lymph nodes (levels I + II ± III) dissection
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + internal mammary lymph nodes dissection
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iverson) mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary and supraclavicular lymph nodes dissection
  • Super radical mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary, supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph nodes dissection.

*Dual-plane mobilisation of breast parenchyma: Mobilisation of the dermoglandular plane and plane between breast parenchyma and pectoralis muscle.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient underwent a modified radical mastectomy for breast cancer. A drain was inserted at the site of the surgery. When can the drain be removed?
questions.solution:
The drain after mastectomy is removed when the output is <30-40 cc for 2 consecutive days. 

The closed system suction drains are put in to prevent the formation of seroma. It is the most common complication of mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection.

questions.text: The following image shows the boundaries of axillary lymph node dissection. The inferior boundary marked as ‘A’ denotes _____.
questions.solution:
The space of axillary lymph node dissection is inferiorly bounded by the angular vein (marked as ‘A’).

Boundaries of axillary lymph node dissection (ALND):

  • Superior - Axillary vein
  • Lateral - Thoracodorsal pedicle
  • Medial - Costoclavicular ligament (Halstead ligament)
  • Inferior - Angular vein    

Indications for ALND:

  1. Locally advanced (T4a, b, c) or inflammatory breast cancer
  2. Metastatic disease in axillary lymph node(s) proven by needle biopsy, clinically palpable or nonpalpable nodes which are abnormal on imaging

Structures preserved during ALND:

  1. Lateral and medial pectoral nerves
  2. Thoracodorsal pedicle

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common complication of mastectomy?
questions.solution:
The most common complication post-mastectomy is the development of a seroma. 

Seroma is a collection of fluid in a surgically created cavity, that results from the transection of vessels and lymphatics. It presents as a localized, well-circumscribed swelling with discomfort. The fluid is clear, yellow, and viscous.

Placement of closed suction drains that obliterate the space between the pectoralis major and skin flap is used to prevent seromas.

Other complications include:

  1. Wound infection
  2. Skin flap breakdown or necrosis
  3. Lymphedema
  4. Hemorrhage

questions.text: After modified radical mastectomy, a patient complained of loss of sensation over the medial aspect of the right upper arm. The nerve most likely damaged is ______.
questions.solution: Resection of the intercostobrachial nerve (ICBN) causes loss of sensation over the medial aspect of the upper arm. The intercostobrachial nerve is the lateral cutaneous branch of the second intercostal nerve.

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for breast carcinoma. She now presents with painless swelling involving the arm as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The generalized swelling of the left arm of the patient post-surgery for breast carcinoma is suggestive of post-mastectomy lymphedema.

Lymphoedema occurs when interstitial fluid accumulates due to defective lymphatic drainage. It is a common complication of breast cancer treatment, involving axillary lymph node dissection and radiotherapy. Sentinel lymph node dissection (SLND) reduces the risk of lymphedema significantly.

Clinical signs and symptoms are observed in the ipsilateral arm. A significant increase in limb size due to swelling is seen. Other symptoms are heaviness, tightness, numbness, tingling, limb fatigue, and reduced limb mobility.

Diagnosis is predominantly based on the clinical swelling of the arm. The girth of the affected arm >2 centimetres than the normal limb, a 200-mL or more increase in limb volume, or a 5% or greater limb volume change are other diagnostic criteria.

Management:

  1. Limb elevation, elastic arm stockings, and pneumatic compression devices to reduce swelling. 
  2. Using a low-pH water-based moisturizer to prevent dry skin caused by excess fluid accumulation. 
  3. Manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) by a therapist followed by simple lymphatic drainage (SLD) by the patient daily aids interstitial fluid evacuation.
  4. Surgical options include lymphaticovenular anastomosis, liposuction, and debulking.

Other options:

Option B:   Stewart-Treves syndrome refers to lymphangiosarcoma seen in chronic long-standing lymphedema following mastectomy (more than 10 years). They present as single/multiple bluish-red skin and subcutaneous nodules. They can ulcerate and hemorrhage.

Option C: Axillary venous thrombosis or Paget-Schrotter disease is seen in patients doing rigorous exercise and in weightlifters. The compression of the subclavian vein at the thoracic outlet causes painful swelling of the arm.

Option D: Cellulitis (lymphangitis) is a bacterial infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It is characterized by a painful area of erythematous and edematous tissue.

questions.text: A  patient presented with acute worsening of edema of the left hand, which was present for the past 5 years. Her surgical history was relevant for a radical mastectomy with radiation therapy for left-sided breast carcinoma. On examination, the limb appears as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image are suggestive of Stewart–Treves syndrome.

The development of angiosarcoma after a combination of postmastectomy lymphedema and radiation therapy is known as Stewart–Treves syndrome. It can arise de-novo or in association with post-mastectomy lymphedema. It presents with acute worsening of edema with subcutaneous nodules which are hemorrhagic or ulcerative.

Treatment is preoperative chemotherapy and radiotherapy followed by surgical excision (radical amputation of arm). The prognosis is poor.

Option A: Tietze syndrome is an inflammatory condition characterized by chest pain and swelling of the cartilage around the ribs at the costochondral junction. 

Option C: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a rare type of cancer that affects the muscle tissue, mostly in children and adolescents.

Option D: Milroy's disease is a familial disease, caused by congenital abnormalities in the lymphatic system. Disruption of the normal drainage of lymph leads to fluid accumulation and hypertrophy of soft tissues.

questions.text: Identify the flap shown in the image used for breast reconstruction.
questions.solution:
The image shows a deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap. It is a free flap and a variant of TRAM flap where only the skin and fat are moved to the chest.

Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous (TRAM) flap is either based on the superior or inferior epigastric artery or both (supercharged TRAM). In a TRAM flap, the skin, fat, and rectus muscle are moved to the chest. 

If robust DIEA perforators are identified with a good caliber and dissection can be performed without dividing the muscle, a DIEP flap is preferred. Otherwise, if small-caliber perforators are encountered and not aligned over the medial or lateral row, a TRAM flap is performed to ensure flap viability.

Option C: Latissimus dorsi (LD) flap is an axial flap based on the thoracodorsal pedicle.

DIEP flap, TRAM flap, and LD flap are autogenous tissues used in breast reconstruction.

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard flap used in breast reconstruction with autogenous tissue?
questions.solution:
The gold standard in breast reconstruction with autogenous tissue is the deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap.

In DIEP flap, using a microvascular technique, only subcutaneous fat and skin are taken, and no muscle is removed. As the muscle is spared, there is a decreased risk of abdominal wall weakness and its associated complications.

Lattismus dorsi flap (LD flap) - does not provide the bulk necessary and an implant is usually required.

Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous flap (TRAM flap):

  • Skin, fat, and muscle are moved to the chest.
  • It is the most commonly used flap.
  • It provides good cosmesis and bulk. An implant is usually not required. 
  • Since the rectus abdominis muscle is excised in the procedure, it can lead to abdominal wall weakness and hernias.

The easiest type of reconstruction is using a silicone gel implant under the pectoralis major muscle. Capsular contraction is a dreaded complication of silicone implants.

In breast reconstruction surgeries, the timing of reconstruction may be immediate or delayed. Impediments to immediate reconstruction include insufficient theatre time and a lack of experienced reconstructive surgeons. In addition, if the patient is likely to need post-op radiotherapy, then a delayed reconstruction using a flap often gives better results.

questions.text:
Which of the following will you not add as part of the chemotherapeutic regime for a patient with breast cancer?
  1. Cyclophosphamide
  2. Fludarabine
  3. Adriamycin
  4. Paclitaxel
  5. Vincristine
questions.solution:
Fludarabine and vincristine are not used in chemotherapy for carcinoma breast.

The present chemotherapy regimen used is ACT regimen, i.e., adriamycin, cyclophosphamide, and taxane (paclitaxel). It comprises 4 cycles of AC followed by 4 cycles of T.

Earlier regimens that are less commonly used currently are as follows:

  • CAF – Cyclophosphamide, Adriamycin, 5-Fluorouracil
  • CMF – Cyclophosphamide, Methotrexate, 5-Fluorouracil

Indications for chemotherapy in carcinoma breast:

  • Lymph nodes positive
  • Lymph nodes negative but tumor size of >1 cm
  • Lymph nodes negative and tumor size of >0.5 cm with
    1. Blood vessel/Lymph vessel invasion
    2. ER/PR –ve
    3. Her-2/neu overexpression
    4. High grade
  • Triple-negative breast carcinoma
  • High recurrence score after Oncotype Dx.

Sacituzumab Govitecan-hziy, a Trop-2-directed antibody and topoisomerase inhibitor drug conjugate recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of adult patients with metastatic triple-negative breast cancer who have received at least two prior therapies.

questions.text: All are aromatase inhibitors used in the treatment of breast cancer except ______.
questions.solution:
Fulvestrant is a selective estrogen-receptor down regulator (SERD).

Selec­tive aromatase inhibitors include:

  • Anastrozole
  • Exemestane
  • Letrozole

They are used for the treatment of breast cancer in postmenopausal women. Selec­tive aromatase inhibitors block the conversion of the hormone androstenedione into estrone by inhibiting the aromatase enzyme. This is the main mechanism of the production of estrogen in postmenopausal women.

questions.text: A woman presented to the OPD with a painless lump in the left breast. Biopsy confirmed the presence of ductal carcinoma. Immunohistochemistry showed ER +ve, PR +ve, and HER2/neu -ve. Which of the following is the latest drug approved for treating this condition?
questions.solution:
Palbociclib is the newest drug approved for metastatic, hormone receptor–positive, HER-2/neu-negative breast cancer.

It is used along with fulvestrant, a selective estrogen-receptor downregulator (SERD) based on the PALOMA 3 trial. 

The US-FDA has recently approved the drug ALPELISIB (PI3K inhibitor) for the treatment of breast cancer in combination with fulvestrant in postmenopausal women.

Related Pearl: Newer drugs in chemotherapy for metastatic breast cancer

Treatment of metastatic breast cancer by targeting PI3k/AKT/mTOR pathways has led to newer chemotherapeutic drugs, which are as follows:

Cyclin-dependent kinase 4/6 inhibitor

  • Palbociclib: Approved for use with aromatase inhibitor (Letrozole) or SERD (Fulvestrant)
  • Ribociclib: Approved for use with aromatase inhibitor (Letrozole)
  • Abemaciclib: Approved for use with SERD (Fulvestrant)

mTOR pathway inhibitors

  • Everolimus:  Approved for treatment of advanced/metastatic hormone receptor–positive, HER-2-negative breast cancer

Phophatidyl-inositol 3 kinase (PI3k) inhibitors

  • Buparlisib – Not approved, but trials are underway for treatment of metastatic breast carcinoma

AKT (Protein kinase B) inhibitors

  • Ipatasertib: Not approved, but found beneficial for metastatic triple-negative breast cancer

questions.text: What is the drug used for estrogen dependant breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that is mainly used for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancers in pre-menopausal women.

It exhibits selective agonistic and antagonistic activity for ER receptors (ERα and ERβ):

  • Agonist activity at the uterus, bone, liver, and pituitary
  • Antagonist activity in breast and blood vessels

Uses: 

  • Part of the primary treatment regimen for estrogen receptor-positive (ER+) breast cancers in pre-menopausal women
  • Adjuvant therapy after breast conservative surgery to prevent a recurrence
  • Tamoxifen also is effective (a 40%–50% reduction in tumor incidence) in preventing ER+ breast cancer in women at increased risk.

Adverse effects: 

  • Vasomotor symptoms (hot flashes) and sweating
  • Endometrial cancer
  • Increased risk of thromboembolic events
  • Fatty liver disease

Related Pearl: Hormonal therapy in breast carcinoma given for ER/PR-positive cases

  • Reduce risk of contralateral breast cancer
  • Reduce risk of progression of in situ to invasive carcinoma

questions.text: A middle-aged woman underwent a trucut biopsy for the suspicion of malignancy on a mammogram. Microscopy showed the presence of invasive breast carcinoma. IHC staining of the tumor is given below. Which of the following drugs will you add along with chemotherapeutic agents for treating this patient?
questions.solution:
The immunohistochemistry staining shown in the above image is ER+, PR+, and HER2+, which is triple positive or luminal type B. Chemotherapy along with endocrine therapy, and trastuzumab is the adjuvant treatment of choice.

Positive immunohistochemistry staining is indicated by the presence of brown-colored tissue.

  • The Estrogen receptor (ER) and Progesterone receptor (PR) are both nuclear receptors, hence, the nucleus is stained brown if positive.
  • The human epidermal growth factor receptor type 2 (HER2) is a membrane receptor, hence the cell membrane is stained brown if positive.

The image below shows positive and negative staining for ER, PR, and HER2.

The adjuvant treatment modalities currently in practice include:

  • Endocrine treatment such as tamoxifen or ovarian suppression. It is given for patients with tumors that are hormone receptor-positive (either ER+ or PR+).
  • Anti-HER2 therapy with trastuzumab (humanized monoclonal antibody). It is given for patients with tumors that are HER2 overexpressing.
  • Chemotherapy is given for hormone negative, HER2+, and ER+ tumors.

The table below shows the summary of the adjuvant treatment approach:

  Tumor hormone receptor status (ER,PR)
Tumor HER2/neu status Positive Negative  
Positive Endocrine therapy + chemotherapy + trastuzumab Chemotherapy + trastuzumab
Negative Endocrine therapy ± chemotherapy Chemotherapy

Note: Palbociclib is used along with hormone therapy in ER +ve, PR +ve, HER2/neu -ve tumors.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

Defining Features

questions.text: A 60 yr old woman underwent a simple mastectomy followed by radiation therapy for ER/PR positive breast cancer. Which of the following is the most appropriate drug to be given to her to prevent the recurrence of breast cancer?

choices.text: No drug is effective to prevent recurrence

questions.solution:
Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor and it is the drug of choice for the prevention of recurrence of ER/PR positive breast cancer in post-menopausal women (usually >50 years). It is given for 10 years.

Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) and it is the drug of choice for preventing recurrence in pre-menopausal women. It has an agonistic action on the endometrium, leading to an increased risk of endometrial cancers. Hence, it is not used in post-menopausal women.

Trastuzumab is a her2/neu receptor antagonist. It is given in patients with her2/neu status positive. It would not be effective in this patient.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about accelerated partial breast irradiation?

choices.text: Irradiation is delivered only at the lumpectomy site
Only suitable for women older than or equal to 65 years of age
It is used for low-risk DCIS patients
It is suitable if surgical margins are negative by ≥ 2 mm

questions.solution:
Accelerated partial breast irradiation (APBI) is a localized form of radiation delivered after lumpectomy to only the part of the breast where the tumor was removed. According to the updated guidelines, patients of age greater than or equal to 50 years are considered suitable for APBI.

Patients of age <40 years are considered unsuitable, while those between 40 and 49 years of age are included in the cautionary group.

According to the recent American Society for Radiation Oncology (ASTRO) guidelines, the following patients are considered suitable for APBI:

  • Patients of age 50 years or older
  • Patients with low-risk DCIS. Low-risk DCIS includes patients satisfying the following criteria-
    1. Screen-detected disease
    2. Low to intermediate nuclear grade
    3. Tumor size ≤ 2.5 cm
    4. Surgical resection with margins negative by ≥ 3mm
  • Patients with surgical margins negative by ≥ 2mm

questions.text:
A postmenopausal woman presented with a 4 cm lump in her left breast. Clinical and radiological examination revealed ipsilateral fixed axillary lymph node involvement without distant metastasis. Histopathology confirms invasive breast carcinoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for ER, PR but negative for HER-2/Neu. What is the best method of management for this patient?
  1. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy
  2. Mastectomy 
  3. Radiation therapy
  4. Trastuzumab
  5. Letrozole
questions.solution:
The best method of management in this patient is neoadjuvant chemotherapy, mastectomy, radiation therapy, and letrozole.

Step 1: Evaluate the TNM staging and stage grouping of the tumor

  • Tumor size 4cm - T2
  • Ipsilateral fixed axillary lymph nodes are positive - N2a
  • No distant metastasis - M0

T2N2M0 belongs to the stage group IIIA which is considered locally advanced breast cancer (LABC). They are treated by neoadjuvant chemotherapy, mastectomy, and radiation therapy.

Step 2: Evaluate the receptor status

The immunohistochemistry is positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors. Therefore the patient has to be started with hormonal therapy with drugs like letrozole, anastrozole, tamoxifen etc.

Trastuzumab / Herceptin is a HER-2/Neu blocker and as the patient is HER2/Neu negative, it would not be effective.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman underwent treatment for breast cancer of 1.2 X 1 cm with positive axillary nodes. She completed radiotherapy and chemotherapy and is now receiving tamoxifen. How would you follow up this patient?

choices.text: Regular checking of LFT once in 6 months
Follow-up with tumour markers once in 6 months

questions.solution:
Follow-up of patients after treatment of breast cancer consists of a physical examination once in 3-6 months for the first 3 years and an annual mammogram.

Mammography is the only imaging modality necessary for follow-up after breast cancer surgery. There is currently no role for tumor markers, serum investigations, or any other imaging studies like bone scans in routine follow-ups.

Guidelines for follow-up after primary treatment:

Physical examination: every 3-6 months for the first 3 years, every 6-12 months for years 4 and 5, and annually thereafter.
Mammography: initially, 6 months after surgery, and thereafter, annually.
Breast self-examination: Monthly 
Pelvic examination: Annually in patients taking tamoxifen

Related Pearl: Breast Cancer Screening

Breast Cancer Screening

Individuals are encouraged to conduct a risk assessment by 25 years of age. This helps classify them into average risk or increased risk groups.

Recommendations: 

  1. Average-risk (no known genetic or family history of breast cancer)
    • 25-39 years of age: clinical breast examination every 1-3 years; 
    • ≥ 40 years of age: clinical breast examination and mammogram annually
  2. High-risk (positive family or genetic history of breast cancer)
    • Consult a healthcare professional every 6-12 months after 21 years of age
    • Annual mammogram or MRI from 25 years of age or 10 years prior to the age at which the youngest family member was diagnosed with breast cancer (whichever is earliest)
  3. Asymptomatic women with previously treated breast cancer
    • Consult a healthcare professional every 6-12 months
    • Annual mammogram
    • Annual MRI to be considered
  4. Mammogram and USG are not contraindicated in pregnant and breastfeeding women

High-risk patients for breast cancer:

  1. Women (or a first-degree relative) with a known BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation or TP53 or PTEN genes
  2. Two first-degree relatives with breast cancers with or without gene mutations
  3. Women with a history of chest irradiation between the ages of 10 and 30
  4. Women with previously biopsy-proven breast cancer
  5. Women with ≥ 20% lifetime risk for breast cancer based on breast cancer risk models

*According to NCCN 2022 guidelines

questions.text: Post-operative radiotherapy is given in a patient with breast carcinoma mainly to _____.

choices.text: Induce ablation of the remnant cancer tissue
Induce ablation of the affected nodes

questions.solution:
The main aim of radiotherapy in breast cancer is to prevent local recurrence.

Radiotherapy is mainly given in the following cases:

  • Positive lymph nodes
  • After breast conservation surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely site for hematogenous spread in a patient with breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Lumbar vertebrae, followed by the femur and thoracic vertebrae, are the most common sites for hematogenous spread of carcinoma breast. Bone metastases in breast cancer are more osteolytic than osteoblastic.

The most common bony sites of blood-borne metastases are as follows:

  • Lumbar vertebrae
  • Femur
  • Thoracic vertebrae
  • Ribs
  • Skull

Note: In prostate cancer, the bone metastases are more osteoblastic than osteolytic.

Related Pearl: Types of metastasis(osteoblastic or osteolytic) and their primary:

Predominantly osteoblastic:

  • Prostate cancer
  • Osteosarcoma 
  • Medullary carcinoma thyroid

Mixed osteoblastic and osteolytic:

  • Breast cancer(preponderance toward osteolytic)
  • Lymphoma
  • Urothelial carcinoma 
  • Lung cancer

Predominantly osteolytic:

  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Multiple myeloma 
  • Thyroid carcinoma(except medullary carcinoma thyroid)
  • Gastrointestinal tract carcinoma
  • Malignant melanoma

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 11-weeks of gestational age presents with a painless lump in the upper quadrant of her left breast. Ultrasound and trucut biopsy revealed the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Perform mastectomy and start chemotherapy immediately after delivery
Mastectomy followed by hormonal therapy in the second and third trimester
Mastectomy followed by chemotherapy in the second and third trimester

questions.solution:
Mastectomy followed by chemotherapy in the second and third trimester is the best step of management in a pregnant woman diagnosed to have breast cancer in the first trimester. 

Pregnancy-associated breast cancer is defined as breast cancer that is diagnosed during pregnancy or within 1 year postpartum. It is the most common non-gy­necologic malignancy associated with pregnancy. Most patients present with a painless mass in the breast with or without bloody nipple discharge.

Diagnosis is done by ultrasonography and tissue biopsy.

Treatment of breast cancer in pregnancy involves:

  • Mastectomy in any trimester along with chemotherapy in the second and third trimesters.
  • Radiotherapy and hormonal therapies are absolutely contraindicated during pregnancy because of teratogenicity. They can be initiated after delivery. 
  • Since radiotherapy is a component of breast conservation therapy, it is contraindicated in the first trimester of pregnancy. However, breast-conserving lumpectomy and axillary lymph node dissection with chemotherapy can be done in the second and third trimesters of pregnancy followed by radiation after delivery.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with back pain that was worse during the night. After evaluation, she was diagnosed with a recurrence of ER/PR+ breast cancer with bony metastasis. Which of the following would be the first-line treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given patient has metastatic breast cancer with bony metastasis. Hormone therapy is the first-line treatment for these patients due to its minimal side effects. It is particularly useful for bony metastasis.

In premenopausal women, tamoxifen, and in post-menopausal women, anastrozole is preferred. 

Chemotherapy is added to the regimen in the following scenarios:

  1. Young woman
  2. Visceral metastasis 
  3. Rapidly growing tumors
  4. Failure of hormonal therapy

Surgery and radiotherapy are sometimes added to the regimen for palliative measures.
